summary: A confidential letter of support for Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed bail application, written by a close friend. The writer describes Maxwell's character, her family life, the media pressure and safety fears she faced after Jeffrey Epstein's death, and asserts her innocence and intention to stand trial.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail application and the letter of support. The writer describes her as a close, honest friend, details her family life, and defends her actions following Jeffrey Epstein's death.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, to whom the confidential letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as having a past connection to Ghislaine Maxwell. His death in August 2019 is cited as a catalyst for increased press interest in Maxwell.

connections.description: The letter references Maxwell's 'past connection to Epstein' as a source of potential civil or criminal allegations.
Described as close friends since 1991, having stayed in each other's homes and families, and providing mutual support.

events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's father died. The writer stayed with her in New York immediately afterward, marking the beginning of their close friendship.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein

events.title: Writer visits Maxwell in hiding

events.title: Renewed Bail Application Submission
events.description: This letter is submitted in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's renewed application for bail.

keyFacts: A close friend provides a character defense of Ghislaine Maxwell, stating she has never known her to be involved in anything unlawful or witnessed inappropriate behavior.
The letter claims Maxwell remained in the United States after Epstein's death to be with family and to be available for any legal proceedings, not to evade law enforcement.
It describes Maxwell living in fear for her safety in 2019, terrified of press, bounty hunters, and conspiracy theorists, leading her to isolate herself.
The letter references the investigation and subsequent dissolution of the charity TerraMar, which was linked to Maxwell, citing media pressure as the cause.
The writer argues Maxwell should be granted bail to properly prepare her defense in a 'non-custodial environment' and asserts she will attend her trial.
